translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The Brahmins’ Questions
Thus have I heard:

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park.

original: Atha kho sambahulā kosalakā brāhmaṇamahāsālā jiṇṇā vuḍḍhā mahallakā addhagatā vayoanuppattā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodiṁsu.
analyzed: atha kho sambahulā kosalakāḥ brāhmaṇa mahāsālāḥ jiṇṇāḥ vuḍḍhāḥ mahallakāḥ addha gatāḥ vayaḥ anuppattāḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamisu upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhim sammodisu
translated: Then many wealthy brahmins from Kosala, old, aged, senior, advanced in years, who had reached the final stage of life, went to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinnā kho te brāhmaṇamahāsālā bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam ekamantam nisīdisu ekamantam nisinnāḥ kho te brāhmaṇa mahā sālāḥ bhagavantam etat avocuḥ
translated: After this exchange of friendly greetings and courtesies, they sat down to one side and said to him:

original: “sandissanti nu kho, bho gotama, etarahi brāhmaṇā porāṇānaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ brāhmaṇadhamme”ti?
analyzed: sandissanti nu khalu bho gotama etarahi brāhmaṇā porāṇānam brāhmaṇānam brāhmaṇa dhamma iti
translated: “Master Gotama, do brahmins nowadays practice the ancient brahmin way?”

original: “Na kho, brāhmaṇā, sandissanti etarahi brāhmaṇā porāṇānaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ brāhmaṇadhamme”ti.
analyzed: na kho brāhmaṇā sandissanti etarahi brāhmaṇā porāṇānam brāhmaṇānam brāhmaṇa dhammā iti
translated: “No, brahmins do not practice the ancient brahmin way.”

original: “Sādhu no bhavaṁ gotamo porāṇānaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ brāhmaṇadhammaṁ bhāsatu, sace bhoto gotamassa agarū”ti.
analyzed: sādhu naḥ bhavam gotamaḥ porāṇānam brāhmaṇānam brāhmaṇa dhammam bhāsatu sace bhoto gotamassa
translated: “It would be good if Master Gotama would teach me the ancient brahmin teaching, if he doesn’t consider it a bother.”

original: “Tena hi, brāhmaṇā, suṇātha, sādhukaṁ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
analyzed: tena hi brāhmaṇā suṇātha sādhukam manasi karotha bhāsissāmi iti
translated: “Then listen and attend closely to what I will say.”

original: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho te brāhmaṇamahāsālā bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: eva bhoti kho te brāhmaṇa mahā sālāḥ bhagavato paccassosu
translated: “Yes, sir,” they replied.
The Buddha said this:
“In the past there were seers
who were self-controlled and austere.
They abandoned the five kinds of sensual stimulation🔽and lived for their own benefit.
The brahmins had no cattle,
no gold or grain.
They lived on the wealth of meditation,
guarding the treasure of the holy life.
Whatever they had received
was set aside for the gate-dwellers.
They thought to give it to them
because of their faith.
With various kinds of cloth,🔽beds, and dwellings,
the prosperous people of the country
paid homage to the brahmins.
The brahmins were respected,
invincible, protected by the Dhamma.
No one could stop them,
At the doors of the families.
For forty-eight years,

analyzed: komāra brahmacariyam te  vijjā ācaraṇa pariyeṭṭhi
translated: They lived the spiritual life;
The brahmins of old practiced🔽The search for knowledge and virtue.
The brahmins did not go elsewhere,
Nor did they buy a wife;
They lived together by mutual consent,
And after coming together they enjoyed themselves.
Except for that time,
When they had intercourse with a female spirit;🔽In between, the brahmins
Did not engage in sexual intercourse.

analyzed: brahmacariyañca sīlam ca  ajjavam maddavam tapa
translated: The spiritual life and virtue,🔽Honesty, gentleness, and austerity;
Friendliness, non-violence,
And patience, they praised.
Even Brahmā, who was their supreme one,
Brahmā of firm strength;
He too did not engage in sexual intercourse,

analyzed: supin ante pi na āgamā  tassa vattam anusikkhantā
translated: Even in a dream.🔽Those who were wise in this world,
Learning his conduct;
The spiritual life and virtue,
And patience, they praised.
Rice, bedding, and cloth,
And ghee and oil, they requested;
Having collected them righteously,
Then they prepared a sacrifice.
At the conclusion of the sacrifice,
they did not kill the cattle.
Just as a mother, a father, a brother,
or any other relative,
Cattle are our supreme friends,
from whom medicinal herbs are born.
They give food, strength, and beauty,
and likewise happiness.
Knowing this benefit,

original: Nāssu gāvo haniṁsu te.🔽Sukhumālā mahākāyā,🔽Vaṇṇavanto yasassino;
analyzed: na assu gāvaḥ hanisu te  sukhumālā mahā kāyā  vaṇṇavantaḥ yasassinaḥ
translated: they did not kill the cattle.🔽The Brahmins, with their fine garlands and large bodies,
beautiful and famous,
diligent in their duties,
as long as they remained in the world,
the people prospered in happiness.

analyzed: tesam āsi vipallāso  disvāna aṇutas aṇu
translated: But they had a perversion,🔽seeing small things as big,
and the appearance of the king,
and the adorned women.

analyzed: rathe ca a jañña sa yutte
translated: The chariots yoked with thoroughbreds,
well-made with jeweled seats,
the houses and abodes,
divided into shares and portions.
Surrounded by a circle of cattle,

analyzed: nārī vara gaṇa āyuta  uḷāram mānusam bhoga
translated: accompanied by a multitude of women,
the Brahmins coveted🔽the abundant human enjoyments.

analyzed: te tattha mante ganthetvā  okkākam tat upāgamu
translated: Having recited the mantras there,🔽they approached Okkāka,
You have abundant wealth and grain,
“Sacrifice with much wealth,
Sacrifice with much money.”
Then the king, the lord of the chariot,
Was urged by the brahmins:🔽“The horse sacrifice, the human sacrifice,
The right-sided, the Vajapeya, the open-air sacrifice;
Having sacrificed in these sacrifices,
He gave wealth to the brahmins.
Cows, beds, and clothes,
Women adorned,

analyzed: rathe ca a jañña sa yutte
translated: Chariots yoked with thoroughbreds,
Well-made, with colorful pennants.
Delightful houses,
Well-divided into sections,
Filled with various grains,
He gave wealth to the brahmins.
And having received that wealth there,
They approved of hoarding it;
For those who had fallen into desire,
Their craving increased even more.
Having chanted the mantras there,
They returned to Okkāka.
Just as water and earth,
Gold, wealth, and riches;
So for humans, cows
Are a necessity, for they are a means of livelihood;
“Sacrifice with much wealth,
Sacrifice with much money.”
Then the king, the lord of the chariot,
The King, the Lord of Chariots,
sacrificed a hundred thousand cows,

original: Gāvo yaññe aghātayi.🔽Na pādā na visāṇena,
analyzed: gāvaḥ yaññe aghātayi  na pādā na visāṇena
translated: in a sacrifice with Brahmins.🔽They did not harm anyone
with their feet or with their horns;
The cows were like young elephants,
gentle, giving milk in abundance;🔽The King seized them by their horns
and had them slaughtered with a knife.

analyzed: tatas devā pitaraḥ ca  indo asura rakkhasā
translated: Then the gods, the ancestors,🔽Inda, the asuras and the rākṣasas,
cried out: “This is unrighteousness!”
as the knife fell on the cows.

original: Tayo rogā pure āsuṁ,🔽Icchā anasanaṁ jarā;
analyzed: tayoḥ rogā pure āsu  icchā anasanam jarā
translated: In the past there were three diseases,🔽desire, hunger and old age;
But because of the oppression of animals,
the disease of leprosy arose.
This unrighteousness with the rod,
the ancient (practice) has come about;
The innocent are killed,
the righteous are destroyed, the sacrificers.
Thus this ancient unrighteousness,
condemned by the wise,
where such (a thing) is seen,
people condemn the sacrificer.

analyzed: evam dhamme viyāpanne  vibhinnā sudda vessikā
translated: Thus when the Dhamma had disappeared,🔽the pure-living were divided;
The Khattiyas were divided into many factions,
and wives despised their husbands.
The Khattiyas, the Brahmins, the relatives of the gods,
and those of other noble families,
Having refuted the claim of birth,
I have gone beyond the control of sensual pleasures.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, te brāhmaṇamahāsālā bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: evam vutte te brāhmaṇa mahā sālāḥ bhagavantam etat avocuḥ
translated: When this was said, the brahmin householders of Bamboo Gate said to the Blessed One:

“Magnificent, Master Gotama! Magnificent, Master Gotama!🔽Master Gotama has made the Dhamma clear in many ways, as though he were turning upright what had been overthrown, revealing what was hidden, showing the way to one who is lost, or holding up a lamp in the dark for those with eyesight to see forms.🔽We go to Master Gotama for refuge and to the Dhamma and to the Sangha of bhikkhus.

original: upāsake no bhavaṁ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupete saraṇaṁ gate”ti.
analyzed: upāsake naḥ bhavam gotamaḥ dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupete saraṇam gatā iti
translated: From today let Master Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone to him for refuge for life.”
The Sutta on the Brahmins’ Code is the seventh.
